CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Violation of P1-1;Pecuniary damage - financial award;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant joined GPE ( GPE ) . He practised as a lawyer until DATE , when he left for GPE . As a result , the NORP authorities deprived him of his NORP citizenship and required him to notify ORG that he had ceased his professional activities and to transfer to his colleagues the cases on which he was then working .

CARDINAL . In a decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG acknowledged the applicant ’s request to cease his professional activities and decided to cancel the applicant ’s membership . According to the applicant , he did not request that his membership of the Bar be cancelled .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant became a member of ORG and practised there as an attorney until DATE .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant applied to ORG to be registered as a lawyer there . On DATE the Chairman of ORG ( PERSON DATE “ the UAR ” ) sent him the following reply :

“ Until a new law concerning lawyers is passed , we can only order the annulment of ORG decision to cancel your membership , so that you may resume your membership of that bar , but you will be deemed ineligible to practise until you return to this country . ... Indeed , the current law does not allow you to be a member of CARDINAL bars , irrespective of the fact that CARDINAL such bar is in this country and the other is abroad . ”
CARDINAL . The Chairman of the ORG confirmed his position in the course of subsequent meetings with the applicant in DATE .

CARDINAL . In DATE , after his NORP citizenship had been restored , the applicant returned to live in GPE . On DATE he applied to ORG for the annulment of the DATE decision , on the ground that he had never requested the cancellation of his ORG membership . He also applied for reinstatement as a lawyer and to be removed from the list of lawyers who were ineligible to practise as he had been a member of another Bar .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG annulled the DATE decision to remove the applicant ’s name from the Bar roll but ordered his re - registration on the list of lawyers ineligible to practise , as he was still a member of another bar .
CARDINAL . DATE the applicant offered investment advice to several multinational corporate clients investing in GPE .
CARDINAL . In DATE he founded a company , PERSON , subsequently renamed ORG , of which he was the sole shareholder and whose main field of activity was business and management consultancy .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to remove the applicant ’s ineligible status and to register his name on the list of practising lawyers with effect from DATE .

CARDINAL . From DATE until DATE , given that he had been reinstated by ORG , he paid DATE Bar fees and ORG fees amounting to CARDINAL NORP lei ( MONEY [ “ EUR ” ] , according to the average exchange rate for the relevant period ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE , in accordance with LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) and the LAW governing ORG , the applicant submitted an application to ORG for a transfer from FAC . He did not receive any response .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG decided that , in accordance with LAW ( j ) of Legislative Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL concerning the organisation and practice of the legal profession , the applicant ’s reinstatement as a lawyer fell within its own field of competence and not that of the Bar . The ORG thus found that ORG had acted ultra vires in taking its decision of CARDINAL DATE . Furthermore , it declared that ORG decision of DATE , annulling the applicant ’s ineligible status , was illegal , having regard to the fact that it had been based on the unlawful decision of DATE .

CARDINAL . It appears that the ORG ’s decision of DATE was never notified either to the applicant or to ORG . The decision was not communicated to him until DATE , when he was involved in other proceedings before ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE , following a communication from ORG , ORG , head of a department of ORG , sent a letter to the Chairman of the ORG pointing out that the applicant ’s re - registration with the Bar in DATE was an act of reparation , that he was the legal adviser for GPE for a number of important companies from GPE mentioned in the letter , and that the best possible ways of resolving his case should be considered in the interests of good relations between the CARDINAL countries .
CARDINAL . On DATE , having received no response to his application for a transfer , the applicant submitted a renewed application to ORG for leave to be transferred from FAC .

CARDINAL . As he did not receive any response , on DATE the applicant brought an action before ORG , in accordance with LAW ( Law no . PERSON ) . He asked the court to establish that he had a right to be transferred from ORG to GPE , to compel the latter to allow his application for a transfer and to issue a decision authorising him to practise as a lawyer in a private law firm .
CARDINAL . Following an application by ORG for a change of venue ( declinare a competentei ) , ORG referred the case to ORG .

CARDINAL . During the proceedings , and following several hearings , ORG invited the applicant to attend a meeting organised by ORG on DATE . The applicant was informed at this meeting that ORG was willing to consider his application for a transfer , provided that he clarified his status with the ORG . He was then told that the ORG had annulled his reinstatement as a member of ORG . The applicant requested ORG to notify him in writing about its position in respect of his application for a transfer . On DATE ORG sent the applicant a letter stating the position which it had expressed orally on DATE and informing him of the ORG ’s decision of DATE .

CARDINAL . At the suggestion of the PERSON of ORG , the applicant requested the ORG on DATE “ to clarify and resolve ” his situation and to advise him of the manner in which his request could be met .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant applied to ORG requesting it to invite the ORG to join as a defendant the proceedings he had brought against ORG . He pointed out that he would be seeking to compel the ORG to disclose its decision of DATE . After several hearings , on CARDINAL DATE the ORG submitted a copy of its decision of DATE to the court .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed an application with the ORG requesting the annulment of that decision and confirmation of his status as a lawyer and a member of ORG , by way of reparation for an abuse committed under the communist regime . He also referred to his letter of DATE to the ORG , pointing out that no answer had been given to his request that the ORG take the necessary decisions in order to clarify his situation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG confirmed its decision of DATE , stating , inter alia , that the applicant had “ committed fraud as he had practised as a lawyer all this time without legal authorisation ” . No information was given to the applicant as to the manner in which his status could be clarified in order to practise as a legally registered lawyer . Similar statements concerning alleged fraud on the applicant ’s part were made by the ORG during the proceedings before ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant instituted proceedings against the ORG before ORG seeking the annulment of the decision of DATE . In his application , he submitted that : following the entry into force of LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL ) , the ORG had had no power to annul ORG decision of DATE ; that , under LAW no . CARDINAL , its decision of DATE was invalid since it had been delivered after the DATE period prescribed by that provision and since only the courts had had jurisdiction to annul in DATE a decision taken in DATE ; and that , as regards the merits of his application , which the court was expressly invited to examine , in the absence of specific regulations indicating where to apply to remedy an unlawful administrative decision deleting him from the GPE list of lawyers , he had acted in good faith , according to the principles of administrative law , when he had lodged his application with ORG in DATE . The applicant pointed out that his administrative application of DATE to the ORG had not constituted a remedy . That case was joined to the proceedings against ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE , during a hearing before ORG , the applicant alleged that the decision of DATE had been unlawful since he had not applied to have his registration as a lawyer cancelled and , consequently , ORG had been entitled to adopt its decision of CARDINAL DATE in order to redress the abuse committed in DATE .

The applicant submitted a number of questions to be answered by the ORG . The ORG replied to the question whether the fact that he had applied to ORG in DATE for the annulment of the DATE decision was unlawful : it considered that the applicant could have lodged such an application with the Bar , but that the decision to be taken fell within the ORG ’s exclusive field of competence . The ORG conceded that the legal basis of its decision of DATE was LAW ( j ) of Legislative Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . As regards the DATE Bar and ORG fees paid by the applicant , the ORG replied that these were insignificant and that , according to the letter of DATE from ORG , the applicant provided legal services to many companies , but he had not established an office for that purpose , nor had he paid the PERCENT fees to the ORG social - security fund , thus committing fraud and unlawfully practising the profession of lawyer .

At the same hearing , suspecting that the decision of DATE had been fabricated at DATE , namely during the proceedings before ORG , the applicant also requested that the ORG ’s original ORG be disclosed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court acceded to the applicant ’s request . However , on DATE it reversed its decision of DATE and ruled that the ORG did not have to disclose the original register . The court declared that , in the absence of a criminal complaint alleging forgery lodged by the applicant against the ORG , it was satisfied that the decision purportedly given on DATE had indeed been given on that date . The court ’s new position was due mainly to the production , by the ORG , of CARDINAL photocopies , CARDINAL being of an undated excerpt of the TIME of a meeting of DATE describing the procedure leading to the impugned decision , and the other being of another page of those minutes with no link to the applicant ’s case . Both these pages bore the stamp of the ORG and the signature of its secretary with the words “ certified copy ” . It is not clear from these documents how many pages the TIME of the meeting of DATE amounted to in all , who signed the TIME or who voted during that meeting .

CARDINAL . The applicant formally objected to that ruling , insisting that it was not his intention to prolong the procedure by lodging a criminal complaint and that the register could easily be disclosed , given that the ORG shared the same building as the court . The applicant ’s objection was dismissed .

CARDINAL . On DATE , during a hearing before ORG , the applicant replied to questions submitted by the ORG . He contended that he had not provided legal services since he had come back to GPE , that he had not practised as a lawyer with an established office and that , consequently , he had not paid PERCENT of his income required by PERSON no . CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s application , holding that , pursuant to LAW no . ORG , ORG had acted ultra vires in taking its decision of CARDINAL DATE , and that , according to LAW ( “ the Rules ” ) issued by the ORG in DATE , the latter had been entitled to annul the decisions of local bars on grounds of illegality . As regards the fact that in DATE the applicant had lodged an application with GPE , considering himself entitled to be reinstated as a lawyer by the body that had unlawfully cancelled his membership with the Bar in DATE , the ORG noted that the DATE decision had been adopted on the basis of a request by the applicant himself .

CARDINAL . The applicant lodged an appeal with ORG against the aforementioned decision of ORG , submitting that that court had not taken into account all the arguments and the evidence submitted . Accordingly , in his grounds of appeal he submitted that the court had erroneously found that he had been at fault for not lodging an application with the competent body in DATE for re - registration as a lawyer , given that he had applied in DATE , on the basis of Law no . DATE , to the body that had taken the unlawful and politically motivated administrative decision of CARDINAL DATE , although he had not requested to be deleted from the Bar ’s list of lawyers . Considering that he should not have had to request to be readmitted to the legal profession because he had been excluded from the ORG by a decision without any legal basis , the applicant had lodged the application with the issuing body , namely ORG , as there was no provision for specific proceedings to redress the effects of such unlawful administrative decisions . The applicant also submitted that , pursuant to the aforementioned LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , which repealed Legislative Decree no . DATE , the ORG had no longer been competent in DATE to annul Bar decisions , and that LAW could not have supplemented that law . The applicant underlined that the ORG ’s decision of CARDINAL DATE had been illegal because the ORG had been time – barred in DATE , according to PERSON no . ORG , and because the legal basis for the decision , namely Legislative Decree no . ORG , had been repealed by PERSON no . CARDINAL .

In his grounds of appeal and also in his written observations to ORG , the applicant added that , according to the documents in the file , the ORG had known since DATE that he had been registered as a lawyer by ORG in DATE , and that , in accordance with LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , the ORG had at that time not only had the power but also the duty to review and possibly annul the decision of CARDINAL DATE by ORG . The applicant referred to the ORG ’s reply to the questions of CARDINAL DATE and concluded that , even supposing that the ORG should have been consulted in DATE by ORG on his re - registration as a lawyer , he was not to blame for lodging the application with that GPE or for the latter ’s or the ORG ’s failure to follow the proper procedure . The applicant requested the court to consider whether it was normal in these circumstances that he could not practise his profession in GPE , and asked it to annul the ORG ’s decision of DATE and to allow his transfer to ORG .

CARDINAL . In a final decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . It held that , in DATE , Legislative Decree no . ORG had vested in ORG the exclusive authority to determine applications relating to the admission or readmission of lawyers to the Bar , and that the provisions of LAW ( g ) and ( i ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL should be interpreted as conserving these prerogatives .

On the basis of LAW , the court rejected the applicant ’s submission that PERSON no . PERSON had removed the ORG ’s powers under LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL to annul Bar decisions , conceding nevertheless that in the text of this law such a power was not expressly maintained . As to the time within which the ORG had been entitled to annul the applicant ’s registration with ORG in DATE , ORG held that , given the issuing body ’s lack of jurisdiction , the annulment could have been decided upon at any time . Finally , ORG pointed out that the annulment of the applicant ’s registration with ORG on the ground of illegality did not remove his right to apply to the competent authority to decide on his application for reregistration as a member of the Bar .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant applied to ORG for registration as a lawyer registered with a foreign Bar , but to date he has not received any reply in spite of the fact that , according to him , in the interim ORG has approved the registration of CARDINAL foreign lawyers .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined the applicant ’s request of DATE to ORG , the latter ’s decision of CARDINAL DATE and the ORG ’s decision of DATE , annulling the applicant ’s registration with ORG . The ORG decided to repeal its decision of DATE , to restore the applicant ’s previous status as a lawyer eligible to practise and to notify this new decision to him and to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG granted the applicant ’s transfer to ORG , ordered his registration on that GPE ’s list of lawyers and decided to notify this decision to him and to ORG .

CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicant stated that on DATE the ORG had notified him of its decision of DATE , and that to date he had not received any formal notification from the GPE concerning its decision of DATE .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW read as follows :
“ An official deed must be adopted in the form required by law , by a public official competent to act in the place where it was adopted . ”

“ An official deed shall be authentic in respect of any person subject to its terms and clauses . The execution of an official deed ... shall be suspended where a criminal complaint is lodged against its author . Where such a complaint alleging forgery is made in the course of civil proceedings , the courts may , depending upon the circumstances , provisionally suspend the execution of the deed . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL ) read as follows :
“ ... the application to the court ( to annul an administrative act ) must be lodged within DATE from the date on which the act is notified . ”
“ ... If a claim is allowed , the court shall also rule on the damages claimed . ”

“ Where the claimant has applied for the annulment of the administrative act without claiming damages at the same time , as the amount of the damage sustained was not known at the time of the examination of the application for annulment , the time allowed for submitting a claim for damages shall run from the date on which he becomes aware of or should have become aware of the damage sustained . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of Legislative Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL concerning certain measures with regard to the organisation and practice of the legal profession provided :
“ ORG UAR ... shall have the following powers ...
( d ) to review decisions taken by the standing committee of the ORG or by ORG and , if it establishes that these decisions are illegal , to annul them ; ...
( j ) to rule on applications for admission or readmission to the Bar and for transfer and secondment of lawyers from CARDINAL Bar to another ; ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) entered into force , repealing Legislative Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . Its relevant provisions read as follows :

“ The Bar shall be required to draw up an DATE roll of qualified and trainee lawyers , in alphabetical order , mentioning their first and last names , academic qualifications and date of admission to the Bar , the place where they practise , their professional capacity and the courts in which they are entitled to plead ...
The Bar shall transmit the DATE list and the modifications thereto to the courts , the investigating authorities , the regional administrative authorities and GPE . ”
“ The Bar Council shall have the following powers : ...
( c ) to prepare , amend and publish the DATE roll of lawyers . It shall transmit this list , with any changes that are necessary , to all interested bodies ; ...
( h ) to acknowledge applications for transfers or secondment within the Bar ;
( i ) to monitor compliance with the conditions set out in this LAW and the Rules as regards the manner of exercise of the profession , and to organise and keep details of such reviews ... ”
“ ORG shall meet on a DATE basis and ... shall have the following powers : ...
( b ) to discuss , approve and modify the Rules governing ORG ; ...
( g ) to approve admission to the Bar in all the cases provided for by the law ; ...
( i ) to rule on complaints against decisions by ORG concerning the refusal of transfer or secondment requests . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL was amended , granting the following powers to ORG in a new section CARDINAL ( i ) :
“ ORG shall have the following powers : ...
( i ) to annul decisions by the Bar on grounds of illegality . ”
CARDINAL . Rule CARDINAL of the Rules governing ORG , adopted by the ORG and published in ORG no . CARDINAL of DATE , provides :
“ Decisions adopted by ORG or by ORG may be annulled by ORG solely on grounds of illegality or a breach of the provisions of the Rules , provided that the Bar ’s autonomy is respected .
Decisions by the PERSON of the Bar may be contested before ORG . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE , in a final judgment ( no . CARDINAL ) , ORG held in proceedings between a private party and the ORG that the latter was an administrative authority with a structure and powers provided for by law , and that LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL ) applied to its decisions .

On DATE , in a final decision ( no . CARDINAL ) , ORG held that the ORG was an administrative authority carrying out administrative acts , that it had a structure and powers established by law , and that it fulfilled a public service role .

On DATE , in a final decision ( no . CARDINAL ) in proceedings against the ORG concerning the right to be admitted to the legal profession without an examination , ORG held that “ it [ was ] undisputed that the decision [ of the ORG was ] an administrative act issued by a public authority ” and that PERSON no . PERSON was applicable to the case .

CARDINAL . On DATE , in a final decision ( no . CARDINAL ) , ORG set aside a decision of an appellate court on the ground that , inter alia , it had reversed without stating reasons a previous order concerning the admission of evidence .
